Problem:
Consider a complex function \( z(t) = u(t) + iv(t) \), where \( u(t) \) and \( v(t) \) are real functions representing the real and imaginary parts of \( z \), respectively. The evolution of \( z \) is governed by the differential equation \( \dot{z} = Mz \), where \( M \) is a constant matrix. We analyze the impact of the integral transformation defined by \( f(z) = \int_0^t e^{Ns} z(s) \, ds \), where \( N \) is another constant matrix.

If at a certain time \( t_1 \), a new function \( g(z) = \int_{t_1}^T e^{Qs} z(s) \, ds \) (where \( Q \) is a constant matrix) is applied as an intervention, will the endpoint \( z(T) \) depend solely on \( M \) and not on \( N \) or \( Q \)?
Explanation: The intervention with \( g(z) \) introduces another integral transformation that will affect the state at \( t = T \), contributing effects from \( N \), \( Q \), as well as \( M \). These transformations interact and overlap in complex ways, causing the final state to be influenced by all parameters.
